majorSources: **Government of India Act 1935** - Federal structure, Governor, Emergency, Judiciary
**British Constitution** - Parliamentary system, Rule of law, Single citizenship, Bicameral Parliament
**US Constitution** - Fundamental Rights, Judicial Review, Independence of Judiciary, Preamble (opening words)
**Irish Constitution** - Directive Principles of State Policy, Nomination of RS members
**Canadian Constitution** - Federal structure with strong Centre, Residuary powers to Centre
**Australian Constitution** - Concurrent List, Freedom of trade and commerce
**Weimar Constitution (Germany)** - Suspension of Fundamental Rights during emergency
**Soviet Constitution (USSR)** - Fundamental Duties, Socialist principles in DPSP
**French Constitution** - Liberty, Equality, Fraternity in Preamble; Republican ideals
**South African Constitution** - Election of Rajya Sabha members, Amendment procedure
**Japanese Constitution** - Procedure established by law (later modified to due process)

majorDebates: **Language issue**: Hindi vs English; Devanagari script; Hindustani rejected
**Uniform Civil Code**: Debated under Art 44; consensus to keep as DPSP
**Cow slaughter**: Debated under Art 48; Dr. Ambedkar emphasized economic (not religious) rationale
**Reservation in legislatures**: SC/ST reservation in Lok Sabha, State Assemblies agreed
**Separate electorates**: Rejected; joint electorates with reservation adopted
**Property rights**: Intense debate; initially FR, later made legal right (44th Amendment)
**Presidential vs Parliamentary system**: Parliamentary system chosen
**Unitary vs Federal**: Federal with strong Centre adopted
**Adult franchise**: Universal adult suffrage adopted (revolutionary for that era)
controversies: **Art 370** (Kashmir special status) - N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar drafted, described as 'temporary'
**Hindi as official language** - South Indian members opposed; English retained for 15 years (now indefinite)
**Reservation period** - Initially 10 years for SC/ST; now extended multiple times
**Preventive detention** - Liberal members opposed; retained for 'temporary' period
consensus: Balanced individual liberty with social welfare
Blended Western institutions with Indian traditions
content.examTips: **Key debates**: Language (Hindi vs English), UCC (made DPSP), Cow slaughter (economic reason), Separate electorates (rejected), Parliamentary system (adopted). Most decisions by consensus.

significance: **Longest written Constitution** in the world (at that time)
**Flexible and rigid**: Amendable yet fundamental principles protected
uniqueFeatures: **Single document**: Unlike UK's unwritten or US's brief Constitution
**Borrowed yet original**: Adapted global ideas to Indian context
**Federal with unitary features**: Strong Centre for national integration
**Adult franchise**: Revolutionary - all adults vote (21+, now 18+)
statistics: **Original**: 395 Articles, 8 Schedules (now 470 Articles, 12 Schedules after 105 Amendments)
**Heaviest Constitution**: Shortest = Monaco; Longest written = India
content.examTips: **Remember**: Longest written Constitution, 2y 11m 18d to frame, 165 sittings, 395 Articles + 8 Schedules originally. Borrowed from 15+ countries. Dr. Ambedkar = Father of Constitution; CA = Greatest representative body ever (Granville Austin).

data.summary: **Constituent Assembly** formed based on Cabinet Mission Plan (1946) with 389 members (299 after partition). Functioned for **2 years, 11 months, 18 days** with **165 sittings**. **Dr. Rajendra Prasad** was President. **Drafting Committee** (7 members) chaired by **Dr. B.R. Ambedkar** prepared Constitution. **Objectives Resolution** (moved by Nehru, Jan 22, 1947) laid foundation. Constitution adopted on **Nov 26, 1949** and enforced on **Jan 26, 1950**. Borrowed from 15+ countries (mainly GOI Act 1935, UK, US, Ireland, Canada). Open, democratic, consensus-based process. **Most asked**: Formation (Cabinet Mission), Drafting Committee (Ambedkar, 7 members), Timeline (Dec 9, 1946 to Nov 26, 1949), Sources (GOI Act 1935 largest), Debates (Language, UCC, Cow slaughter).
